metadata.sermon_title: At Calvary: Two Words At The End
metadata.sermon_start_end: When Jesus therefore had received the vinegar, he said, It is finished: and he bowed his head, and gave up the ghost. (John 19:30) And when Jesus had cried with a loud voice, he said, Father, into thy hands I commend my spirit: and having said thus, he gave up the ghost. [...] And then, please God, we shall be able to say, 'I've done what you told me. It is finished, not cut off, but finished. Father, take me into thy hands. Put a light in the window. Let some old friends stand in the doorway to welcome us home. Father, into thy hands.' And then with a shout we may cross over.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses two distinct passages but fails to identify what is unique to these specific texts. Instead of finding what is 'nowhere else in the Bible,' the preacher treats the texts as a springboard for a general narrative of the Passion and a psychological reflection on 'homecoming.' The specificity of John's 'Tetelestai' versus Luke's 'Paratithemai' is blurred into a single emotional arc.
quotes: The divine plan to win us back to the Father's house was worked out in the pilgrimage Jesus... made from Bethlehem to Calvary.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Isolate the specific theological weight of John 19:30 (legal/liturgical completion) from Luke 23:46 (filial trust) rather than blending them into a general sentiment.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of Greek or Hebrew knowledge, nor a serious engagement with the historical or theological context of the specific Gospel writers. The preacher uses the Old Testament (Isaiah, Jeremiah) as a speculative psychological backdrop for Jesus' inner thoughts rather than performing rigorous exegesis of the primary texts.
quotes: In the silent years of which we have no record, it may be that Jesus pondered that mission. It could be that he mused upon the prophets.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Replace speculative psychological reconstructions of Jesus' childhood with an analysis of the Greek terms used for 'finished' and 'commend' within their respective Gospel contexts.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application attempts concreteness by mentioning drugs and social decay, but it quickly retreats into sentimental imagery ('light in the window'). It lacks the 'broad knowledge of the humanities' Dekker requires, opting for clichés over a sharp analysis of the zeitgeist.
quotes: families in ruins, lives torn to pieces... young men and women 'dead on arrival' from overdoses of drugs.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond listing social ills; analyze how the 'finished' work of Christ specifically addresses the modern person's sense of being 'lost in time' or the 'misery' of the current cultural moment.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a narrative journey followed by a moralistic application. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' to be expounded by it; rather, the text is used to illustrate a pre-existing idea of a 'journey home.'
quotes: I think, oh, not in such grand and cosmic terms, but I think that these last words may belong to all of us.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'I think' transition where the preacher shifts from the text to his own thoughts. Let the application emerge directly from the grammatical and theological structure of the verse.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The three parts are present in the background. Misery is identified (sin's consequences), redemption is central (the cross), and gratitude is hinted at in the 'I must' section. However, the 'misery' is described more as social dysfunction than misery 'before God.'
quotes: The idea of sin may have passed, but the misery it produces is very much with us.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by showing it as a theological condition (alienation from God) rather than just a list of social problems.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon leans heavily toward a universal 'homecoming' sentiment. While 'Hell' is mentioned as having lost, the actual possibility of the hearer being 'lost' (temporal or eternal) is not presented as a serious, urgent choice. It lacks the 'narrow way' tension.
quotes: The long search is finished and the lost and wandering child has been found and brought home.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Incorporate the 'two ways' by addressing the possibility of remaining 'lost in time' if the call to 'the Father's business' is ignored.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the strongest point. Christ is clearly the telos and the source of grace. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the description of the 'pilgrimage' of the Son of God. However, the conclusion shifts the focus back to human effort ('I must').
quotes: At Calvary, God's ancient intention to lift the awful load of sin from the world is now an accomplished deed, fait accompli.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure that the 'I must' of the believer is clearly a fruit of the 'It is finished' of Christ, rather than a separate moral requirement for entry into heaven.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 950 words, the sermon would take less than 10 minutes to deliver. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for theological 'depth.' It is a meditation, not a sermon.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition and application to meet the 20-minute minimum requirement to allow for substantive theological development.

overall_assessment.summary: The text falls short of Dekker’s definition of a sermon primarily due to its brevity and lack of rigorous exegesis. It functions as a sentimental narrative rather than a specific exposition of a Bible passage. The preacher relies on psychological speculation and general social observations rather than the 'specific word' found only in these texts. The duration is critically insufficient for the depth Dekker demands.
strengths: Strong Christocentric focus on the 'accomplished deed' of the cross.
Clear attempt to link the 'misery' of the world (drugs, crime) to the theological necessity of the cross.
weaknesses: Critically short duration (under 10 minutes) prevents theological breadth.
Lack of Greek/Hebrew engagement and historical-critical depth.
Sentimentalized application that borders on moralism in the final section.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the Dekkerian sense; it is a brief devotional address. It lacks the formal requirements of exposition and the substantive requirement of depth through breadth.
